head.title: The Long and the Short of Campaigning

hedline.hl1: The Long and the Short of Campaigning

block.p: I was all set to announce my candidacy for mayor of my town (''Narayanan Subramania for mayor of Sleepy Hollow'' -- it had a nice ring to it) when I was stopped cold in my tracks by a campaign aide who brought to my attention Jeff Greenfield's June 6 Op-Ed article about how the names of candidates are getting shorter and shorter.
Memories came up of many first days at work, when a new co-worker (invariably a Gary or a Larry) would say upon being introduced, ''Now, what can we call you for short -- Nary?''

I was all set to announce my candidacy for mayor of my town (''Narayanan Subramania for mayor of Sleepy Hollow'' -- it had a nice ring to it) when I was stopped cold in my tracks by a campaign aide who brought to my attention Jeff Greenfield's June 6 Op-Ed article about how the names of candidates are getting shorter and shorter.
Memories came up of many first days at work, when a new co-worker (invariably a Gary or a Larry) would say upon being introduced, ''Now, what can we call you for short -- Nary?''
Or the times when a fellow with a with an unpronounceable last name would ask for permission to mongrelize my last name -- to make it pronounceable, of course -- to ''submarine''!
NARAYANAN SUBRAMANIA Sleepy Hollow, N.Y., June 6, 2000
